_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary:

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Polices:

The Talecris Biotheraputics, Inc. facility, located in Clayton, NC, is a pharmaceutical plant which produces plasma therapies using a plasma refractionation process.  Many of the process steps occurring at the Talecris facility take place at temperature below 32 degrees F, and thus ammonia refrigeration systems are used to cool and or freeze materials at various steps throughout the process.  

The technologies used by Talecris require the use of chemicals which fall under the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) requirements.  As part of itA?s compliance program, the Talecris facility complies with the OSHA PSM standard for ammonia; the guidelines published by the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR), for equipment specification and operating procedures; and the American Industrial Hygiene Association (AIHA) for emergency response.  If an emergency were to occur, it is the facility policy to notify the Clayton, NC Fire Department and request that they respond.

Stationary Source of Regulated Substances:

The Talecris Biotheraputics, Inc. facility is located on approximately 182 acres roughly 2 A? miles southeast of downtown Clayton, NC.  A CSX railroad line runs through the middle of the Clayton facility separating the main production facility, to the south of the railroad tracks, from the main ammonia refrigeration facility, the A?North PlantA?, located on the north side of the railroad line.

Facility inventories indicate that the typical system charge is 27,500 pounds of ammonia.  The largest vessels in the system are two (2) high-pressure receivers which measure 11 feet long by 66 inches in diameter for a capacity of approximately 262 cubic feet or 10,451 pounds of ammonia.  These vessels are typically operated at 40 percent capacity, but could be filled to 88 percent capacity under NFPA code.  The 88 percent value of 9,200

pounds of ammonia is used in worst case release scenario calculations for this facility.  A failure in one of the receiver vessels would not cause a failure of the other vessel due to the spacing of the vessels and the presence of appropriately sized pressure relief valves on each vessel.

Worst Case Release Scenario and The Alternative Release Scenario:

Using EPAA?s A?Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia RefrigerationA? the worst case release scenario was determined to be the failure of a high pressure receiver when filled to itsA? maximum operation capacity of 9,200 pounds (88%).  The high pressure receiver is contained within a building therefore the effects of passive mitigation were used in determining the maximum distance a toxic endpoint.  The distance to this endpoint is a circle centered on the A?North PlantA? with a 1.0 mile radius equivalent to the toxic endpoint concentration of 0.14 mg/l.

The worst case impact zone contains residential homes with a population of approximately 550 people.  Public receptors located within the worst case impact zone are a daycare center (0.7 miles) and the Powhatan Church (0.4 miles).  One environmental receptor, an unnamed tributary of the Neuse River (0.2 miles), is also located in the impact zone.

The alternative scenario chosen is the rupturing of a A? inch diameter pipe.  The machine room is equipped with an exhaust/water curtain system and an emergency dump system.  With this in mind passive and active mitigation systems were accounted for in estimating the distance to the toxic endpoint.  The alternative scenario produced a circle with a radius of 0.1 miles.  There are no public or environmental receptors within the impact zone.

Accident Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps:

The Talecris Clayton, NC facility complies with EPAA?s accident prevention rule and all applicable state and local codes and regulations.  The building and the equipment used as part of the ammonia refr

igeration process are designed with the prevention of accidents in mind.  Written procedures are in place to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures.  Audits are conducted on a regularly scheduled basis to determine if all safety provisions are being properly implemented and to verify that suggested corrective actions are completed.  A preventative maintenance program is in place with scheduled maintenance procedures for compressors, pumps, evaporators, condensers, control valves, ammonia detectors, and emergency response equipment.  Any incident that results in or could have resulted in an injury or the release of ammonia is promptly investigated and reported upon.  Talecris employees are encouraged to voice their views on accident prevention issues and to recommend possible changes in order to make safety management and accident prevention a team effort with the ultimate goal of preventing a catastrophic release of ammonia.

Five Year Accident History:

The Clayton, NC facility has not had an ammonia release of a reportable nature (greater than 100 pounds) in the last five years.  

One accident occurred at the facility on March 6, 2007 which involved the personal injury of a contract worker requiring hospitalization.  The worker was attempting to repair a heat exchanger with an internal tube leak.  The individual in question grasped a valve port fitting on the side of an ammonia to water heat exchanger and used the fitting for leverage to try climb up to gain a better position for the work he was performing on the heat exchanger.  The tube broke off from the heat exchanger and the worker was sprayed over the face and upper torso with an approximately 50% saturated solution of ammonia and water.  The release of ammonia was inside of a building and was contained in the area of the incident, so no offsite receptors were impacted.

The investigation for this incident determined that the valve port had suffered internal corrosion at

the seam between the heat exchanger wall and the valve port tube causing failure in the shell metal on the heat exchanger.  The total release of ammonia was approximately one pound and lasted less than one minute.  Following the incident the heat exchanger was replaced and the system in that area reconfigured to prevent a similar occurrence in the future.  

Emergency Response Program:

Talecris has a written emergency response plan which is on file with the Johnston County Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC).  The Clayton facility also has an on-site Emergency Response Team which receives training on firefighting, hazardous materials, and emergency medical treatment.  The Emergency Response Team meets, drills and services their equipment on a regular scheduled basis.  Talecris closely communicates with the local and county response teams including the Clayton Fire Department and the Johnston County LEPC.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

At this time there are two planned changes that will ultimately improve the safety of the ammonia refrigeration system.  One involves the replacement and reconfiguring of the ammonia system evaporative condensers located on the A?North PlantA? roof which will allow for easier maintenance and monitoring.  The second involves the relocation of a system pump out compressor from the floor of the Compressor Room to the roof.  This will also allow for easier maintenance and monitoring of the system.  Management of Change and PHA revision procedures will be followed during these upgrades.
